Subelement.title: FCC Rules, descriptions and definitions for the Amateur Radio Service, operator and station license responsibilities

Group.title: Amateur Radio Service: purpose and permissible use of the Amateur Radio Service; operator/primary station license grant; where FCC rules are codified; basis and purpose of FCC rules; meanings of basic terms used in FCC rules; interference; spectrum management

Question.text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service as stated in the FCC rules and regulations?

Answer.text: Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art
All of these choices are correct

Question.Explanation: There are multiple purposes to the Amateur Radio Service but advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art is the most important one.

Question.text: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?

Answer.text: The ITU
The FCC
Homeland Security

Question.Explanation: FCC regulates Amateur Radio Service in the United States.

Question.text: Which part of the FCC regulations contains the rules governing the Amateur Radio Service?

Answer.text: Part 73
Part 95
Part 90
Part 97

Question.Explanation: Part 97 contains almost all FCC regulations dealing with the Amateur Radio Service.

Question.text: Which of the following meets the FCC definition of harmful interference?

Answer.text: Radio transmissions that annoy users of a repeater
Unwanted radio transmissions that cause costly harm to radio station apparatus
That which seriously degrades, obstructs, or repeatedly interrupts a radio communication service operating in accordance with the Radio Regulations
Static from lightning storms

Question.Explanation: Anything that negatively impacts a radio communication service of other legal users is a harmful interference.

Question.text: Which of the following is a purpose of the Amateur Radio Service rules and regulations as defined by the FCC?

Answer.text: Enhancing international goodwill
Providing inexpensive communication for local emergency organizations
Training of operators in military radio operating procedures
All of these choices are correct

Question.Explanation: One of purposes of the Amateur Radio Service as defined in FCC 97.1 is to enhance interational goodwill.

Question.text: Which of the following services are protected from interference by amateur signals under all circumstances?

Answer.text: Citizens Radio Service
Broadcast Service
Land Mobile Radio Service
Radionavigation Service

Question.Explanation: Due to its importance and critical nature, radionavigation service gets a special treatment in relation to interference by the Radio Amateur Service.

Question.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of telemetry?

Answer.text: An information bulletin issued by the FCC
A one-way transmission to initiate, modify or terminate functions of a device at a distance
A one-way transmission of measurements at a distance from the measuring instrument
An information bulletin from a VEC

Question.Explanation: Any one-way transmission of a measurement by an instrument is considered a telemetry data.

Question.text: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?

Answer.text: Frequency Spectrum Manager
Frequency Coordinator
FCC Regional Field Office
International Telecommunications Union

Question.Explanation: Frequency coordinator is an entity that recommends channels and other parameters so that interference can be minimized or avoided.

Question.text: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?

Answer.text: The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be auxiliary or repeater stations
FCC Regional Field Office

Question.Explanation: Frequency coordinator is selected by Amateur operators themselves.

Question.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of an amateur station?

Answer.text: A station in the Amateur Radio Service consisting of the apparatus necessary for carrying on radio communications
A building where Amateur Radio receivers, transmitters, and RF power amplifiers are installed
Any radio station operated by a non-professional
Any radio station for hobby use

Question.Explanation: Anything that has possiblity of carrying on the radio communication under control of an amateur operator is a amateur station.

Question.text: When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?

Answer.text: Only if the station being interfered with is expressing extreme religious or political views
At no time
Only during a contest
At any time, amateurs are not protected from willful interference

Question.Explanation: Willful interference is not allowed at any time.

Question.text: Which of the following is a permissible use of the Amateur Radio Service?

Answer.text: Broadcasting music and videos to friends
Providing a way for amateur radio operators to earn additional income by using their stations to pass messages
Providing low-cost communications for start-up businesses
Allowing a person to conduct radio experiments and to communicate with other licensed hams around the world

Question.Explanation: Communication and radio experiments are one of purposes of the Amateur Radio Service.

Question.text: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of telecommand?

Answer.text: An instruction bulletin issued by the FCC
A one-way radio transmission of measurements at a distance from the measuring instrument
A one-way transmission to initiate, modify or terminate functions of a device at a distance
An instruction from a VEC

Question.Explanation: Tele-command is a radio instruction toward a device.

Question.text: What must you do if you are operating on the 23 cm band and learn that you are interfering with a radiolocation station outside the United States?

Answer.text: Stop operating or take steps to eliminate the harmful interference
Nothing, because this band is allocated exclusively to the amateur service
Establish contact with the radiolocation station and ask them to change frequency
Change to CW mode, because this would not likely cause interference

Question.Explanation: If you are interfering with any radiolocation, stop the interference yourself.

Group.title: Authorized frequencies: frequency allocations; ITU regions; emission modes; restricted sub-bands; spectrum sharing; transmissions near band edges

Question.text: What is the ITU?

Answer.text: An agency of the United States Department of Telecommunications Management
A United Nations agency for information and communication technology issues
An independent frequency coordination agency
A department of the FCC

Question.text: Why are the frequency assignments for some U.S. Territories different from those in the 50 U.S. States?

Answer.text: Some U. S. Territories are located in ITU regions other than region 2
Territorial governments are allowed to select their own frequency allocations
Territorial frequency allocations must also include those of adjacent countries
Any territory that was in existence before the ratification of the Communications Act of 1934 is exempt from FCC frequency regulations

Question.text: Which frequency is within the 6 meter band?
Which amateur band are you using when your station is transmitting on 146.52 MHz?

Answer.text: 2 meter band
20 meter band
14 meter band
6 meter band

Question.text: Which 70 cm frequency is authorized to a Technician Class license holder operating in ITU Region 2?
Which 23 cm frequency is authorized to a Technician Class licensee?

Answer.text: 2315 MHz
1296 MHz
3390 MHz

Question.text: What amateur band are you using if you are transmitting on 223.50 MHz?

Answer.text: 15 meter band
10 meter band
2 meter band
1.25 meter band

Question.text: Which of the following is a result of the fact that the amateur service is secondary in some portions of the 70 cm band?

Answer.text: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in the bands, and must avoid interfering with them
U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those portions
International communications are not permitted on 70 cm
Digital transmissions are not permitted on 70 cm

Question.text: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?

Answer.text: To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
To allow for transmitter frequency drift
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the bands above 30 MHz that are available to Technician Class operators have mode-restricted sub-bands?

Answer.text: The 6 meter, 2 meter, and 70 cm bands
The 2 meter and 13 cm bands
The 6 meter, 2 meter, and 1.25 meter bands
The 2 meter and 70 cm bands

Question.text: What emission modes are permitted in the mode-restricted sub-bands at 50.0 to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 to 144.1 MHz?

Answer.text: CW only
CW and RTTY
SSB only
CW and SSB

Question.text: Why are frequency assignments for U.S. stations operating maritime mobile not the same everywhere in the world?

Answer.text: Amateur maritime mobile stations in international waters must conform to the frequency assignments of the country nearest to their vessel
Amateur frequency assignments can vary among the three ITU regions
Frequency assignments are determined by the captain of the vessel
Amateur frequency assignments are different in each of the 90 ITU zones

Question.text: Which emission may be used between 219 and 220 MHz?

Answer.text: Spread spectrum
SSB voice
Fast-scan television

Group.title: Operator licensing: operator classes; sequential, special event, and vanity call sign systems; international communications; reciprocal operation; station license and licensee; places where the amateur service is regulated by the FCC; name and address on FCC license database; license term; renewal; grace period

Question.text: Which type of call sign has a single letter in both its prefix and suffix?

Answer.text: Special event

Question.text: Which of the following is a valid US amateur radio station call sign?
What types of international communications are permitted by an FCC-licensed amateur station?

Answer.text: Communications incidental to the purposes of the amateur service and remarks of a personal character
Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
Only communications incidental to contest exchanges, all other communications are prohibited
Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station

Question.text: When are you allowed to operate your amateur station in a foreign country?

Answer.text: When the foreign country authorizes it
When there is a mutual agreement allowing third party communications
When authorization permits amateur communications in a foreign language
When you are communicating with non-licensed individuals in another country

Question.text: Which of the following is a vanity call sign which a technician class amateur operator might select if available?

Answer.text: All of these choices are correct

Question.text: From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit, in addition to places where the FCC regulates communications?

Answer.text: From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunications Union
From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
From anywhere within in ITU Regions 2 and 3
From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

Question.text: What may result when correspondence from the FCC is returned as undeliverable because the grantee failed to provide the correct mailing address?

Answer.text: Fine or imprisonment
Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license
Require the licensee to be re-examined
A reduction of one rank in operator class

Question.text: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued primary station/operator amateur radio license grant?

Answer.text: Five years
Ten years
Twenty years

Question.text: What is the grace period following the expiration of an amateur license within which the license may be renewed?

Answer.text: Two years
Three years
Five years
Ten years

Question.text: How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you operate a transmitter on an amateur service frequency?

Answer.text: 30 days after the test date
As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database
You must wait until you receive your license in the mail from the FCC

Question.text: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to operate a transmitter on amateur service frequencies?

Answer.text: No, transmitting is not allowed until the FCC license database shows that the license has been renewed
Yes, but only if you identify using the suffix GP
Yes, but only during authorized nets
Yes, for up to two years

Question.text: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?

Answer.text: Only licensed amateurs with general or extra class licenses
Only licensed amateurs with an extra class license
Only an amateur licensee who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years
Any licensed amateur

Question.text: For which licenses classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?

Answer.text: Novice, Technician, General, Advanced
Technician, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
Novice, Technician Plus, General, Advanced
Technician, General, Amateur Extra

Question.text: Who may select a vanity call sign for a club station?

Answer.text: Any Extra Class member of the club
Any member of the club
Any officer of the club
Only the person named as trustee on the club station license grant

Group.title: Authorized and prohibited transmission: communications with other countries; music; exchange of information with other services; indecent language; compensation for use of station; retransmission of other amateur signals; codes and ciphers; sale of equipment; unidentified transmissions; broadcasting

Question.text: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur stations prohibited from exchanging communications?

Answer.text: Any country whose administration has notified the ITU that it objects to such communications
Any country whose administration has notified the ARRL that it objects to such communications
Any country engaged in hostilities with another country
Any country in violation of the War Powers Act of 1934

Question.text: On which of the following occasions may an FCC-licensed amateur station exchange messages with a U.S. military station?

Answer.text: During an Armed Forces Day Communications Test
During a Memorial Day Celebration
During an Independence Day celebration
During a propagation test

Question.text: When is the transmission of codes or ciphers that hide the meaning of a message allowed by an amateur station?

Answer.text: Only during contests
Only when operating mobile
Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft
Only when frequencies above 1280 MHz are used

Question.text: What is the only time an amateur station is authorized to transmit music?

Answer.text: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications
When the music produces no spurious emissions
When the purpose is to interfere with an illegal transmission
When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz

Question.text: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?

Answer.text: When the equipment is normally used in an amateur station and such activity is not conducted on a regular basis
When the asking price is $100.00 or less
When the asking price is less than its appraised value
When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee or the control operator or their close relatives

Question.text: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?

Answer.text: The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
Any such language is prohibited
The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
There is no such prohibition

Question.text: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?

Answer.text: Auxiliary, beacon, or Earth stations
Auxiliary, repeater, or space stations
Beacon, repeater, or space stations
Earth, repeater, or space stations

Question.text: In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating the station?

Answer.text: When engaging in communications on behalf of their employer
When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution
When re-broadcasting weather alerts during a RACES net
When notifying other amateur operators of the availability for sale or trade of apparatus

Question.text: Under which of the following circumstances are amateur stations authorized to transmit signals related to broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?

Answer.text: Only where such communications directly relate to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property
Only when broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
Only where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network
Only when using amateur repeaters linked to the Internet

Question.text: What is the meaning of the term “broadcasting” in the FCC rules for the amateur services?

Answer.text: Two-way transmissions by amateur stations
Transmission of music
Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

Question.text: When may an amateur station transmit without identifying?

Answer.text: When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
When the transmissions are unmodulated
When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
When transmitting signals to control a model craft

Question.text: Under which of the following circumstances may an amateur radio station engage in broadcasting?

Answer.text: Under no circumstances
When transmitting code practice, information bulletins, or transmissions necessary to provide emergency communications
At any time as long as no music is transmitted
At any time as long as the material being transmitted did not originate from a commercial broadcast station

Group.title: Control operator and control types: control operator required; eligibility; designation of control operator; privileges and duties; control point; local, automatic and remote control; location of control operator

Question.text: When is an amateur station permitted to transmit without a control operator?

Answer.text: When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station

Question.text: Who may a station licensee designate to be the control operator of an amateur station?

Answer.text: Any U.S. citizen or registered alien
Any family member of the station licensee
Any person over the age of 18
Only a person for whom an amateur operator/primary station license grant appears in the FCC database or who is authorized for alien reciprocal operation

Question.text: Who must designate the station control operator?

Answer.text: The station licensee
The FCC
The frequency coordinator
The ITU

Question.text: What determines the transmitting privileges of an amateur station?

Answer.text: The frequency authorized by the frequency coordinator
The class of operator license held by the station licensee
The highest class of operator license held by anyone on the premises
The class of operator license held by the control operator

Question.text: What is an amateur station control point?

Answer.text: The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
The location of the station transmitting apparatus
The location at which the control operator function is performed
The mailing address of the station licensee

Question.text: Under what type of control do APRS network digipeaters operate?
When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?

Answer.text: All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
Only the station licensee
Only the control operator
The control operator and the station licensee are equally responsible

Question.text: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?

Answer.text: Repeater operation
Controlling the station over the Internet
Using a computer or other device to automatically send CW
Using a computer or other device to automatically identify

Question.text: What type of control is being used when the control operator is at the control point?

Answer.text: Radio control
Unattended control
Automatic control
Local control

Question.text: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?

Answer.text: Repeater operation
Operating the station over the Internet
Controlling a model aircraft, boat or car by amateur radio
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?

Answer.text: The station custodian
The third party participant
The person operating the station equipment
The station licensee

Question.text: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician Class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an exclusive Extra Class operator segment of the amateur bands?

Answer.text: At no time
When operating a special event station
As part of a multi-operator contest team
When using a club station whose trustee is an Extra Class operator licensee

Group.title: Station identification; repeaters; third party communications; club stations; FCC inspection

Question.text: What type of identification is being used when identifying a station on the air as Race Headquarters?

Answer.text: Tactical call sign
An official call sign reserved for RACES drills
Broadcast station

Question.text: When using tactical identifiers such as “Race Headquarters” during a community service net operation, how often must your station transmit the station’s FCC-assigned call sign?

Answer.text: Never, the tactical call is sufficient
Once during every hour
At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication
At the end of every transmission

Question.text: When is an amateur station required to transmit its assigned call sign?

Answer.text: At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
At least once during each transmission
At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

Question.text: Which of the following is an acceptable language to use for station identification when operating in a phone sub-band?

Answer.text: Any language recognized by the United Nations
Any language recognized by the ITU
The English language
English, French, or Spanish

Question.text: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?

Answer.text: Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
Send the call sign using CW or phone emission
Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
Send the call sign using only phone emission

Question.text: Which of the following formats of a self-assigned indicator is acceptable when identifying using a phone transmission?

Answer.text: KL7CC stroke W3
KL7CC slant W3
KL7CC slash W3
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a Technician Class control operator?

Answer.text: The person must be a U.S. citizen
The foreign station must be one with which the U.S. has a third party agreement
The licensed control operator must do the station identification
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which indicator is required by the FCC to be transmitted after a station call sign?

Answer.text: /M when operating mobile
/R when operating a repeater
/ followed the FCC Region number when operating out of the region in which the license was issued
/KT, /AE or /AG when using new license privileges earned by CSCE while waiting for an upgrade to a previously issued license to appear in the FCC license database

Question.text: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?

Answer.text: Beacon station
Earth station
Repeater station
Message forwarding station

Question.text: Who is accountable should a repeater inadvertently retransmit communications that violate the FCC rules?

Answer.text: The control operator of the originating station
The control operator of the repeater
The owner of the repeater
Both the originating station and the repeater owner

Question.text: To which foreign stations do the FCC rules authorize the transmission of non-emergency third party communications?

Answer.text: Any station whose government permits such communications
Those in ITU Region 2 only
Those in ITU Regions 2 and 3 only
Those in ITU Region 3 only

Question.text: How many persons are required to be members of a club for a club station license to be issued by the FCC?

Answer.text: At least 5
At least 4
A trustee and 2 officers
At least 2

Question.text: When must the station licensee make the station and its records available for FCC inspection?

Answer.text: At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
At any time upon request by an FCC representative
Only after failing to comply with an FCC notice of violation
Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent

Group.title: Station operation: choosing an operating frequency; calling another station; test transmissions; procedural signs; use of minimum power; choosing an operating frequency; band plans; calling frequencies; repeater offsets

Question.text: What is the most common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?

Answer.text: Plus 500 kHz
Plus or minus 600 kHz
Minus 500 kHz
Only plus 600 kHz

Question.text: What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 70 cm band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?

Answer.text: Plus or minus 5 MHz
Plus or minus 600 kHz
Minus 600 kHz
Plus 600 kHz

Question.text: What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?

Answer.text: Say break, break then say the station's call sign
Say the station's call sign then identify with your call sign
Say CQ three times then the other station's call sign
Wait for the station to call CQ then answer it

Question.text: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?

Answer.text: Transmit CQ followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign
Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign

Question.text: What must an amateur operator do when making on-air transmissions to test equipment or antennas?

Answer.text: Properly identify the transmitting station
Make test transmissions only after 10:00 p.m. local time
Notify the FCC of the test transmission
State the purpose of the test during the test procedure

Question.text: Which of the following is true when making a test transmission?

Answer.text: Station identification is not required if the transmission is less than 15 seconds
Station identification is not required if the transmission is less than 1 watt
Station identification is only required once an hour when the transmissions are for test purposes only
Station identification is required at least every ten minutes during the test and at the end of the test

Question.text: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?

Answer.text: Call on the quarter hour
A new antenna is being tested (no station should answer)
Only the called station should transmit
Calling any station

Question.text: What brief statement is often transmitted in place of “CQ” to indicate that you are listening on a repeater?

Answer.text: The words “Hello test” followed by your call sign
Your call sign
The repeater call sign followed by your call sign
The letters “QSY” followed by your call sign

Question.text: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?

Answer.text: A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band
A mandated list of operating schedules
A list of scheduled net frequencies
A plan devised by a club to indicate frequency band usage

Question.text: Which of the following is an FCC rule regarding power levels used in the amateur bands, under normal, non-distress circumstances?

Answer.text: There is no limit to power as long as there is no interference with other services
No more than 200 watts PEP may be used
Up to 1500 watts PEP may be used on any amateur frequency without restriction
While not exceeding the maximum power permitted on a given band, use the minimum power necessary to carry out the desired communication

Question.text: Which of the following is a guideline to use when choosing an operating frequency for calling CQ?

Answer.text: Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
Ask if the frequency is in use
Make sure you are in your assigned band
All of these choices are correct

Group.title: VHF/UHF operating practices: SSB phone; FM repeater; simplex; splits and shifts; CTCSS; DTMF; tone squelch; carrier squelch; phonetics; operational problem resolution; Q signals

Question.text: What is the term used to describe an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?

Answer.text: Full duplex communication
Diplex communication
Simplex communication
Multiplex communication

Question.text: What is the term used to describe the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?

Answer.text: Carrier squelch
Tone burst

Question.text: Which of the following describes the muting of receiver audio controlled solely by the presence or absence of an RF signal?

Answer.text: Tone squelch
Carrier squelch
Modulated carrier

Question.text: Which of the following common problems might cause you to be able to hear but not access a repeater even when transmitting with the proper offset?

Answer.text: The repeater receiver may require an audio tone burst for access
The repeater receiver may require a CTCSS tone for access
The repeater receiver may require a DCS tone sequence for access
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What determines the amount of deviation of an FM (as opposed to PM) signal?

Answer.text: Both the frequency and amplitude of the modulating signal
The frequency of the modulating signal
The amplitude of the modulating signal
The relative phase of the modulating signal and the carrier

Question.text: What happens when the deviation of an FM transmitter is increased?

Answer.text: Its signal occupies more bandwidth
Its output power increases
Its output power and bandwidth increases
Asymmetric modulation occurs

Question.text: What could cause your FM signal to interfere with stations on nearby frequencies?

Answer.text: Microphone gain too high, causing over-deviation
SWR too high
Incorrect CTCSS Tone
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?

Answer.text: Common courtesy should prevail, but no one has absolute right to an amateur frequency
Whoever has the strongest signal has priority on the frequency
Whoever has been on the frequency the longest has priority on the frequency
The station which has the weakest signal has priority on the frequency

Question.text: Which of the following methods is encouraged by the FCC when identifying your station when using phone?

Answer.text: Use of a phonetic alphabet
Send your call sign in CW as well as voice
Repeat your call sign three times
Increase your signal to full power when identifying

Question.text: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?
Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?
Under what circumstances should you consider communicating via simplex rather than a repeater?

Answer.text: When the stations can communicate directly without using a repeater
Only when you have an endorsement for simplex operation on your license
Only when third party traffic is not being passed
Only if you have simplex modulation capability

Question.text: Which of the following is true of the use of SSB phone in amateur bands above 50 MHz?

Answer.text: It is permitted only by holders of a General Class or higher license
It is permitted only on repeaters
It is permitted in at least some portion of all the amateur bands above 50 MHz
It is permitted only on when power is limited to no more than 100 watts

Group.title: Public service: emergency and non-emergency operations; applicability of FCC rules; RACES and ARES; net and traffic procedures; emergency restrictions

Question.text: When do the FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?

Answer.text: When operating a RACES station
When operating under special FEMA rules
When operating under special ARES rules
Never, FCC rules always apply

Question.text: What is one way to recharge a 12-volt lead-acid station battery if the commercial power is out?

Answer.text: Cool the battery in ice for several hours
Add acid to the battery
Connect the battery in parallel with a vehicle’s battery and run the engine
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What should be done to insure that voice message traffic containing proper names and unusual words are copied correctly by the receiving station?

Answer.text: The entire message should be repeated at least four times
Such messages must be limited to no more than 10 words
Such words and terms should be spelled out using a standard phonetic alphabet
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What do RACES and ARES have in common?

Answer.text: They represent the two largest ham clubs in the United States
Both organizations broadcast road and weather information
Neither may handle emergency traffic supporting public service agencies
Both organizations may provide communications during emergencies

Question.text: Which of the following describes the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?

Answer.text: A radio service using amateur frequencies for emergency management or civil defense communications
A radio service using amateur stations for emergency management or civil defense communications
An emergency service using amateur operators certified by a civil defense organization as being enrolled in that organization
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice to get the immediate attention of a net control station when reporting an emergency?

Answer.text: Repeat the words SOS three times followed by the call sign of the reporting station
Press the push-to-talk button three times
Begin your transmission by saying "Priority" or "Emergency" followed by your call sign
Play a pre-recorded emergency alert tone followed by your call sign

Question.text: Which of the following is an accepted practice for an amateur operator who has checked into an emergency traffic net?

Answer.text: Provided that the frequency is quiet, announce the station call sign and location every 5 minutes
Move 5 kHz away from the net's frequency and use high power to ask other hams to keep clear of the net frequency
Remain on frequency without transmitting until asked to do so by the net control station
All of the choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of good emergency traffic handling?

Answer.text: Passing messages exactly as received
Making decisions as to whether or not messages should be relayed or delivered

Convert electrical energy into radio waves

A type of voltage regulator

To increase the current carrying capability of the wire
To prevent coupling of unwanted signals to or from the wire

A unit combining the functions of a transmitter and a receiver
A component in a repeater which filters out unwanted interference

Question.text: Which of the following devices is most useful for VHF weak-signal communication?

Group.title: Common transmitter and receiver problems: symptoms of overload and overdrive; distortion; causes of interference; interference and consumer electronics; part 15 devices; over and under modulation; RF feedback; off frequency signals; fading and noise; problems with digital communications interfaces

Question.text: What can you do if you are told your FM handheld or mobile transceiver is over-deviating?

Answer.text: Talk louder into the microphone
Let the transceiver cool off
Change to a higher power level
Talk farther away from the microphone

The microphone gain of the transmitter is turned up too high

Question.text: Which of the following may be a cause of radio frequency interference?

Spurious emissions
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a way to reduce or eliminate interference by an amateur transmitter to a nearby telephone?

Answer.text: Put a filter on the amateur transmitter
Reduce the microphone gain
Reduce the SWR on the transmitter transmission line

Question.text: How can overload of a non-amateur radio or TV receiver by an amateur signal be reduced or eliminated?

Switch the transmitter to a narrow-band mode

Question.text: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?

Answer.text: Make sure that your station is functioning properly and that it does not cause interference to your own radio or television when it is tuned to the same channel

Low-pass and high-pass filters

Question.text: What should you do if something in a neighbor’s home is causing harmful interference to your amateur station?

Answer.text: Work with your neighbor to identify the offending device
Politely inform your neighbor about the rules that prohibit the use of devices which cause interference

All of these choices are correct

A type of test set used to determine whether a transmitter is in compliance with FCC regulation 91.15

Question.text: What might be the problem if you receive a report that your audio signal through the repeater is distorted or unintelligible?

Your batteries may be running low
You could be in a bad location

Question.text: What is the primary purpose of a dummy load?

To prevent over-modulation of your transmitter

1 to 2

Question.text: What does an SWR reading of 4:1 indicate?

Answer.text: Loss of -4dB
Good impedance match
Gain of +4dB
Impedance mismatch

It comes back into your transmitter and could cause damage

It can cause distortion of your signal

Gamma rays

Answer.text: Ultraviolet resistant jackets prevent harmonic radiation
Ultraviolet light can increase losses in the cable’s jacket
Ultraviolet and RF signals can mix together, causing interference

It cannot be used for VHF or UHF antennas

Question.text: Which of the following is a common use of coaxial cable?

Answer.text: All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is a safety hazard of a 12-volt storage battery?

All of these choices are correct

All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of these precautions should be taken when installing devices for lightning protection in a coaxial cable feed line?

Answer.text: Include a parallel bypass switch for each protector so that it can be switched out of the circuit when running high power
Include a series switch in the ground line of each protector to prevent RF overload from inadvertently damaging the protector
Keep the ground wires from each protector separate and connected to station ground
Ground all of the protectors to a common plate which is in turn connected to an external ground

Question.text: What safety equipment should always be included in home-built equipment that is powered from 120V AC power circuits?

Answer.text: A fuse or circuit breaker in series with the AC hot conductor
An AC voltmeter across the incoming power source
An inductor in series with the AC power source
A capacitor across the AC power source

Question.text: What kind of hazard is presented by a conventional 12-volt storage battery?

Answer.text: It emits ozone which can be harmful to the atmosphere
Shock hazard due to high voltage
Explosive gas can collect if not properly vented
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What can happen if a lead-acid storage battery is charged or discharged too quickly?

Answer.text: The battery could overheat and give off flammable gas or explode
The voltage can become reversed
The memory effect will reduce the capacity of the battery
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What kind of hazard might exist in a power supply when it is turned off and disconnected?

Answer.text: Static electricity could damage the grounding system
Circulating currents inside the transformer might cause damage
The fuse might blow if you remove the cover
You might receive an electric shock from the charged stored in large capacitors

Group.title: Antenna safety: tower safety; erecting an antenna support; overhead power lines; installing an antenna

Question.text: When should members of a tower work team wear a hard hat and safety glasses?

Answer.text: At all times except when climbing the tower
At all times except when belted firmly to the tower
At all times when any work is being done on the tower
Only when the tower exceeds 30 feet in height

Question.text: What is a good precaution to observe before climbing an antenna tower?

Answer.text: Make sure that you wear a grounded wrist strap
Remove all tower grounding connections
Put on a climbing harness and safety glasses
All of the these choices are correct

Question.text: Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?

Answer.text: When no electrical work is being performed
When no mechanical work is being performed
When the work being done is not more than 20 feet above the ground

Question.text: Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?

Answer.text: Wear a ground strap connected to your wrist at all times
Insulate the base of the tower to avoid lightning strikes
Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is the purpose of a gin pole?

Answer.text: To temporarily replace guy wires
To be used in place of a safety harness
To lift tower sections or antennas
To provide a temporary ground

Question.text: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?

Answer.text: Half the width of your property
The height of the power line above ground
1/2 wavelength at the operating frequency
So that if the antenna falls unexpectedly, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

Question.text: Which of the following is an important safety rule to remember when using a crank-up tower?

Answer.text: This type of tower must never be painted
This type of tower must never be grounded
This type of tower must never be climbed unless it is in the fully retracted position
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What is considered to be a proper grounding method for a tower?

Answer.text: A single four-foot ground rod, driven into the ground no more than 12 inches from the base
A ferrite-core RF choke connected between the tower and ground
Separate eight-foot long ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other
A connection between the tower base and a cold water pipe

Question.text: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?

Answer.text: The antenna will not work properly because of induced voltages
The utility company will charge you an extra monthly fee
The antenna could contact high-voltage power wires
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following is true concerning grounding conductors used for lightning protection?

Answer.text: Only non-insulated wire must be used
Wires must be carefully routed with precise right-angle bends
Sharp bends must be avoided
Common grounds must be avoided

Question.text: Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?

Answer.text: FCC Part 97 Rules
Local electrical codes
FAA tower lighting regulations
Underwriters Laboratories' recommended practices

Question.text: Which of the following is good practice when installing ground wires on a tower for lightning protection?

Answer.text: Put a loop in the ground connection to prevent water damage to the ground system
Make sure that all bends in the ground wires are clean, right angle bends
Ensure that connections are short and direct
All of these choices are correct

Group.title: RF hazards: radiation exposure; proximity to antennas; recognized safe power levels; exposure to others; radiation types; duty cycle

Question.text: What type of radiation are VHF and UHF radio signals?

Answer.text: Gamma radiation
Ionizing radiation
Alpha radiation
Non-ionizing radiation

Question.text: Which of the following frequencies has the lowest value for Maximum Permissible Exposure limit?

Answer.text: 3.5 MHz
50 MHz
440 MHz
1296 MHz

Question.text: What is the maximum power level that an amateur radio station may use at VHF frequencies before an RF exposure evaluation is required?

Answer.text: 1500 watts PEP transmitter output
1 watt forward power
50 watts PEP at the antenna
50 watts PEP reflected power

Question.text: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?

Answer.text: Frequency and power level of the RF field
Distance from the antenna to a person
Radiation pattern of the antenna
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?

Answer.text: Lower frequency RF fields have more energy than higher frequency fields
Lower frequency RF fields do not penetrate the human body
Higher frequency RF fields are transient in nature
The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

Question.text: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine that your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?

Answer.text: By calculation based on FCC OET Bulletin 65
By calculation based on computer modeling
By measurement of field strength using calibrated equipment
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: What could happen if a person accidentally touched your antenna while you were transmitting?

Answer.text: Touching the antenna could cause television interference
They might receive a painful RF burn
They might develop radiation poisoning
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Which of the following actions might amateur operators take to prevent exposure to RF radiation in excess of FCC-supplied limits?

Answer.text: Relocate antennas
Relocate the transmitter
Increase the duty cycle
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?

Answer.text: By informing the FCC of any changes made in your station
By re-evaluating the station whenever an item of equipment is changed
By making sure your antennas have low SWR
All of these choices are correct

Question.text: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?

Answer.text: It affects the average exposure of people to radiation
It affects the peak exposure of people to radiation
It takes into account the antenna feed line loss
It takes into account the thermal effects of the final amplifier

Question.text: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?

Answer.text: The difference between the lowest power output and the highest power output of a transmitter
The difference between the PEP and average power output of a transmitter
The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting
The percentage of time that a transmitter is not transmitting

Question.text: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?

Answer.text: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause genetic damage
RF radiation can only be detected with an RF dosimeter
RF radiation is limited in range to a few feet
RF radiation is perfectly safe

Question.text: If the averaging time for exposure is 6 minutes, how much power density is permitted if the signal is present for 3 minutes and absent for 3 minutes rather than being present for the entire 6 minutes?

Answer.text: 3 times as much
1/2 as much
2 times as much
There is no adjustment allowed for shorter exposure times
